CatDescriptText: Mrs. Frances Harris, housewife, Uptown and Mr. Theodore Branson, steel mill worker, 317 Robinson Ct. were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 20, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe fares would be lower and service better on trolleys and buses if the city owned and operated these services?"  Mrs. Harris' answer reads: " There's a good possibility that the city could run the trolleys and buses at a cheaper rate and give better service." Mr. Branson's answer reads: " I suppose that the fares would be cheaper and the service better if the city operated the trolleys and buses.  And the reason, is because it wouldn't be so much a matter of profit, but an operation by the city, at cost, for the benefit of the riders.  however, I don't think the rates would be reduced a whole lot."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Frances Harris wearing light colored sleeveless blouse with figurative pattern, standing in front of brick building; Portrait of Theodore Branson wearing straw hat with plaid band, standing in front of building
